Award.AwardTitle: Rapid Synthesis of Epitaxial Semiconductors for Energy Applications

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant will develop new manufacturing approaches to the formation of critical materials and structures required for next generation solar cells. Current manufacturing technologies are based on batch processing of semiconductors, typically using slow epitaxial growth rates. This work will demonstrate that continuous processing can be a new approach to thin film epitaxial solar cell manufacturing that will enable rapid, high growth rate synthesis of epitaxial semiconductor materials. Tasks include the development of prototype manufacturing equipment, novel optimization approaches and product quality measurements. Existing material growth models will be extended to explore the rate- limiting steps and these models will be used to mitigate the development of point defects which affect the device performance.

The outcome of this research will be both the knowledge of the materials properties synthesized at high growth rates as well as approaches for improving their performance in solar applications. The rapid synthesis of semiconductor materials and the understanding of the impact of very high growth rate on materials properties provide fundamental information required to open new manufacturing regimes. The work of this grant will develop the design and optimization approaches for new classes of semiconductor manufacturing tools. The widespread development and expansion of several technologies, specifically solar photovoltaics and solid-state lighting, which are both key to the energy field, will benefit from the new approaches in tool design and process development as they move to a continuous, non-batch processing that can provide new economies and open new process design approaches which have been unexplored and unexploited.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research enabled new approaches to the development of
manufacturing tools and processes enabling the rapid formation of
solar cell materials. The research was a collaboration between groups
experienced in the synthesis of semiconductors for solar energy, and in
reactor design and process optimization.  Gallium Arsenide is a
semiconductor which has the best match to the solar spectrum for the
terrestrial generation solar energy. In order to enable higher
efficiency and lower cost solar cells, the design and development of
new manufacturing tools is needed. The process, hydride vapor phase
epitaxy or HVPE, shows great promise for meeting the current and
future goals for low-cost solar cell production. The research formed
detailed models of the process-properties-cell efficiency. These are
the first models that connect manufacturing level properties with cell
efficiency and hence eventually the pricing models. The cell
efficiency models connected gas phase compositions during formation to
the detailed defect concentrations in the synthesized materials. It is
these defects that limit solar cell efficiency. Such process models
are now being used to optimize and design the reactor used for the
formation of the materials, optimizing the reactor geometry and flow
conditions without the need to do extensive and costly
experimentation, thus speeding the design and implementation of the
process.

Materials processing and manufacturing tool optimization are strategic
areas in advanced manufacturing that the US should maintain its
leading position in the world. The process models, as well as the
knowledge generated in tool optimization from this research,
contributes to the US leading position in this important area. The
hydride vapor phase epitaxy technique is being seriously researched by
government and commercial interests as a next generation approach to
high efficiency thin film solar cells and this research provides
fundamental understanding of the processing relationship need to
further the technology.

The research provided opportunities for undergraduate and graduate
students to gain deep understanding of complex physical phenomena in
solar energy materials processing through both experimental and
computational studies. The research allowed for the interaction of
undergraduate and graduate students between the research and workers
in the national labs and commercial interests in the energy sector.
